newsitem.title: CANADA: Allelix Biopharm CEO sees Q1 loss.
newsitem.headline: Allelix Biopharm CEO sees Q1 loss.

text.p: Biotechnology firm Allelix Biopharmaceuticals Inc will post a loss in its first quarter after an unexpected profit in its fourth quarter, chief executive Graham Strachan said on Wednesday.
"We will not show a profit in the first quarter," Strachan told Reuters in an interview. "We'll show the losses you see in a development company."

Toronto-based Allelix earned C$0.29 a share in its fourth quarter ended August 31, versus a year earlier loss of C$0.64. The profit was due partly to a supplier's decision to delay an expensive shipment of a hormone for research.

The supplier delayed the shipment until Allelix's new fiscal year ending August 31, 1997. Allelix also received a C$6.8 million payment from partner Astra AB as part of its agreement with the Swedish drug firm. Astra bought exclusive worldwide rights to a possible osteoporosis treatment from Allelix in one of Canada's largest drug deals.
Strachan said he did not know how deep the loss would be. "It's hard to say at this point," he said, adding the quarter had not ended.
In its fiscal 1996 first quarter, which ended November 30, 1995, Allelix lost C$0.35 a share or C$3.9 million.
Linda Willis, Allelix's vice-president of finance, said "The fact that we had income last quarter was an anomaly because of a larger payment."

Allelix's osteoporosis product, called PTH (Human Parathyroid Hormone), was in advanced clinical trials called Phase II trials, Strachan said. The hormone rebuilds brittle bone eaten away by osteoporosis, a disease afflicting about 200 million people around the world.

Allelix was also developing a treatment to attack the Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV), which causes Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome (AIDS). The potential product ALX40-4C was also in Phase I/II combined clinical trials, Willis said.
Allelix shares rose 0.15 to 15.75 in light trading on the Toronto Stock Exchange, below the year high of 26, but above the year low of 10.625.
